text: it happened half a century ago Bloody
Sunday a massacre on the Edmund Pettus
Bridge in Selma Alabama blacks getting
beaten for daring to demand the right to
vote a recent movie called Selma
dramatized the prominent role that dr.
Martin Luther King jr. played in that
cause but there's another story not as
well known about segregation in the
south and dr. King played a part in that
too me know three weeks before Bloody
Sunday dr. King urged the people of
Gee's Bend Alabama to go to Camden to
vote his visit fed a continuing fight
over a small ferry that rode the Alabama
River a fight that would last for
decades
I think relations are at a good point
now I really do it's two societies in
one location separate and still unequal
they came as slaves more than a decade
before the Civil War and never left
generation after generation made a home
on Gee's Bend
a small Peninsula on the Alabama River
across the river was Camden the seed of
Wilcox County which in the 1960s was as
segregated a place as any other in the
south when dr. King made one of his
visits to the county in 1966 Rosetta
Anderson a young mother at the time went
to the Antioch Baptist Church to see him
we had got rumors that if he came here
they were gonna bomb the church
she says dr. King never did step inside
the church he stood outside on a raised
platform you see me standing over in the
crowd like this and I was trying to let
it all soak in most important thing he
spoke about but this was all about for
us having the right to vote but allowing
blacks to vote that's what white
segregationists feared the most in the
1960s and had been fighting against for
years with literacy tests poll taxes and
violence there were no elected black of
issues thirty years later Earl Hilliard
became the first african-american
elected to Congress from Alabama since
reconstruction
and they were afraid that blacks would
out vote them eventually a vote them out
of office so they did everything they
could use every type of device of
vehicle to keep blacks from vote some
time in 1962 in the midst of the
protests white segregationists in Camden
resorted to what seemed to be a dirty
trick the only way they could get those
african-american citizens from
protesting and they keep them from
protesting was to get rid of the mode of
transportation which was the ferry and
they did that
it was just an old creaky raft something
out of the pages of Huckleberry Finn but
it was the quickest way to cross the
river to Camden yes you could drive but
few people on the bend had cars then so
when the ferry vanished from the river
it further isolated them kept them from
their jobs from shopping made it more
difficult for kids to get to school even
when local quilts earned the bend and
national reputation there still wasn't a
doctor or an ambulance on the bend when
you realize you're talking about
in some cases an hour I wouldn't have
before you can get medical service you
can realize the impact that that had
over a period of years after Hilliard
was elected to Congress in the 1990s he
fought to bring the ferry back he found
an unlikely ally in Camden newspaper
editor Hollis curl of vigorous
segregationist for most of his life curl
did an about-face claiming he realized
racism was wrong
curl who also owned property along the
river lobbied hard for the return of the
ferry this story made national news
there's a lot yet to be done to heal the
divisiveness of the past and I like to
think that that this ferry is a step in
that in that direction nevertheless it
was a long time before ferry service was
restored for decades change has finally
come to a small town in the deep south
they joined in celebration blacks and
whites together when the Bender's
finally got a new ferry this time a real
one but after such a long delay what
difference does a ferry make the fact is
blacks are the majority in Wilcox County
and they're largely in political control
now one exception max Baggett jr.
Camden's mayor baguette is sanguine
about race relations here I don't think
there has been that terrible
relationship between the blacks and
whites ever particularly the ones in
Gees been you know the white people hold
most of the land they have most of the
money and the blacks we still have to go
to them for everything ferry or no ferry
not much has changed here the school's
segregated back in the day are still
largely segregated and more than 39
percent of the predominantly black
population in the area live below the
poverty line
there are few jobs and very little
industry Jo Celeste Pettway the first
black female to be appointed a district
court judge in Alabama says there's
still a lot for young people to overcome
it's something you have to teach your
children that you don't want to have to
teach them I had to teach my child when
you stopped by policeman put your hands
on the steering wheel don't make any
sudden movements if they ask you
something is yes sir no sir yes ma'am no
ma'am and you speak kindly to get
through that incident that situation
quite parents don't have to teach their
children there
the Sun sets over the Alabama River the
Gees been ferry crosses over making its
last run of a long day on the bend Tana
Pettway a preacher and schoolteacher
shows the way to the gravestones of the
original Pettway family mark Pettway a
white man migrated to Gee's Bend in 1846
with a caravan of 100 black slaves one
of the daughters
despite its seclusion and small
population of 275 Tana Pettway has plans
for Gee's Bend o truly believe that the
future of these men is still gonna be
great
he wants to see it turned into a tourist
attraction perhaps then the ferry could
find its place in history there was some
things that were accomplished there was
some things that were left undone in
many ways I feel that the ferry is
symbolic of the story of the civil
rights movement
